item.title: CScripts
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Metho D, post:17, topic:431172”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=533852.msg3903059#msg3903059 date=1327953109]

Yeah, they did have client scripts in the older RT3, but not in this sense. So far, only numbers between 0 and 20, with various functions (get current skill level, get current config state, etc)

Ah, varp. Not the same thing.
[/quote]

I think you’re thinking of something else. The script system in the 377 client had 20 instructions, like zyle1992 mentioned, and it supported the basic arithmetic operations. It was only used for replacing text on a widget or determining if a widget was “active” (e.g. if a spell icon should be lit), though.

I’ve uploaded a renamed version of the method in the 377 client here.[/quote]

Oh the interface scripting system.

Edit: Congrats on java cup. Well deserved.

Read full topic

item.title: CScripts
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Metho D, post:17, topic:431172”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=533852.msg3903059#msg3903059 date=1327953109]

Yeah, they did have client scripts in the older RT3, but not in this sense. So far, only numbers between 0 and 20, with various functions (get current skill level, get current config state, etc)

Ah, varp. Not the same thing.
[/quote]

I think you’re thinking of something else. The script system in the 377 client had 20 instructions, like zyle1992 mentioned, and it supported the basic arithmetic operations. It was only used for replacing text on a widget or determining if a widget was “active” (e.g. if a spell icon should be lit), though.

I’ve uploaded a renamed version of the method in the 377 client here.[/quote]

Yes, I was up for a few hours last night looking at what the different types of settings do (the wrong way). Renaming the client certainly helped when identifying what the different opcodes do.

Read full topic

I think you’re thinking of something else. The script system in the 377 client had 20 instructions, like zyle1992 mentioned, and it supported the basic arithmetic operations. It was only used for replacing text on a widget or determining if a widget was “active” (e.g. if a spell icon should be lit), though.

I’ve uploaded a renamed version of the method in the 377 client here.

item.description:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:14, topic:431172”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=533852.msg3903059#msg3903059 date=1327953109]

Yeah, they did have client scripts in the older RT3, but not in this sense. So far, only numbers between 0 and 20, with various functions (get current skill level, get current config state, etc)

Ah, varp. Not the same thing.
[/quote]

Varp? I though that Varbit dealt with the config states?[/quote]
I think varbit deals with the more ‘physical’ configuration states.

Read full topic

Yeah, they did have client scripts in the older RT3, but not in this sense. So far, only numbers between 0 and 20, with various functions (get current skill level, get current config state, etc)

Ah, varp. Not the same thing.
[/quote]

Varp? I though that Varbit dealt with the config states?[/quote]

Variable protocol and variable bit files are not the same thing.

item.title: CScripts
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Metho D, post:10, topic:431172”]Instructions 4008-4010 look like bitset, bitclear, and bittest instructions.

Are these instructions the same in the RT3 client?

The 474 client looked like it had a newer script system in it when I briefly looked at it yesterday, but the 317 and 377 clients both use the older one. I’m not sure if the 474 client uses the RT3 engine or not.[/quote]

They are. 4000-4099 are purely numeric based.

        INSN_NAMES.put(4000, "IADD");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4001, "ISUB");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4002, "IMUL");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4003, "IDIV");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4004, "getRandom");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4005, "getRandom2");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4008, "toggleBit");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4009, "untoggleBit");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4010, "isBitToggled");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4011, "IMOD");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4012, "IPOW");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4014, "IAND");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4015, "IOR");

Didn’t see an integer XOR instruction.

317 is the older RT3, 414 is when the modern RT3 engine came out. Why they didn’t divide it into two separate engines I don’t know.

Read full topic

item.title: CScripts
item.dc:creator: @Metho_D Method
item.description:
@Metho_D wrote:

Instructions 4008-4010 look like bitset, bitclear, and bittest instructions.

zyle1992:

Are these instructions the same in the RT3 client?

The 474 client looked like it had a newer script system in it when I briefly looked at it yesterday, but the 317 and 377 clients both use the older one. I’m not sure if the 474 client uses the RT3 engine or not.

Read full topic

item.title: CScripts
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

zyle1992:

Are these instructions the same in the RT3 client?

Well, if it has main_cache_index.idx12 then it has client scripts. I’d expect to see this after mid RT3 (~414-508).

Read full topic

item.title: CScripts
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Metho D, post:5, topic:431172”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=533852.msg3902641#msg3902641 date=1327900002]
I knew you know more about this but I didn’t have your MSN so thank you.[/quote]

It hasn’t changed. I still have your account on my contact list (unless you’ve changed it).

[quote author=sinisoul link=topic=533852.msg3902641#msg3902641 date=1327900002]
Do you still have that long list of instructions you rewrote still with you? Mind posting it?[/quote]

I don’t think I have (or ever did have?) a list of instructions and corresponding descriptions.[/quote]

You did because I remember you and I talking about the instructions because it came up in conversation. I cleaned out my MSN so I might have deleted you (on accident) so I’ll be sure to add you again.

Updated the dump.

Rewrote most of the math instructions, still working on it:

        INSN_NAMES.put(4000, "IADD");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4001, "ISUB");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4002, "IMUL");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4003, "IDIV");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4004, "getRandom");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4005, "getRandom2");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4008, "toggleBit");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4009, "untoggleBit");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4010, "isBitToggled");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4011, "IMOD");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4012, "IPOW");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4014, "IAND");
        INSN_NAMES.put(4015, "IOR");

My first attempt at rewriting a script:

function script3381(arg0, arg1) {
	arg1++
	setInterfaceDefinitionScriptParams0(3381, arg0, arg1, "Ii", arg0)
	if arg1 > 1 then
		_G.arg1273 = 1
		setInterfaceDefinitionScriptParams0(-1 ,"", arg0)
		doScript(2945)
	end
}

Sort of lua-y. _G is the global table index (kinda the same, not really).

================================================
      Client Script 3381 Dumped by SiniSoul    
================================================

================================================
                 Instructions                   
================================================

Offset: 0, LOADINT , Operand: 1
Offset: 1, PUSHI , Operand: 1
Offset: 2, IADD , Operand: 0
Offset: 3, STOREINT , Operand: 1
Offset: 4, PUSHI , Operand: 3381
Offset: 5, LOADINT , Operand: 0
Offset: 6, LOADINT , Operand: 1
Offset: 7, PUSHS , Operand: Ii
Offset: 8, LOADINT , Operand: 0
Offset: 9, setInterfaceDefinitionScriptParams0 , Operand: 0
Offset: 10, LOADINT , Operand: 1
Offset: 11, PUSHI , Operand: 1
Offset: 12, IFGT , Operand: 1
Offset: 13, GOTO , Operand: 7
Offset: 14, PUSHI , Operand: 1
Offset: 15, STOREGINT , Operand: 1273
Offset: 16, PUSHI , Operand: -1
Offset: 17, PUSHS , Operand: 
Offset: 18, LOADINT , Operand: 0
Offset: 19, setInterfaceDefinitionScriptParams0 , Operand: 0
Offset: 20, CALL , Operand: 2945
Offset: 21, RETURN , Operand: 0

item.title: CScripts
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Metho D, post:2, topic:431172”]Here are a few questions and comments that I had:

[ul][]What is JUMP? Is that the switch instruction?
[]What is ENDSCRIPT? Is that return?
[]Instruction 40 is the call instruction.
[]Instruction 6 is an unconditional jump, i.e., a goto instruction.
[]Instructions 7-10 and 31-32 are conditional jump instructions.
[]Instruction 37 concatenates strings.[/ul][/quote]

I knew you know more about this but I didn’t have your MSN so thank you. Do you still have that long list of instructions you rewrote still with you? Mind posting it?

Read full topic

item.title: CScripts
item.dc:creator: @Metho_D Method
item.description:
@Metho_D wrote:

Here are a few questions and comments that I had:

[ul][]What is JUMP? Is that the switch instruction?
[]What is ENDSCRIPT? Is that return?
[]Instruction 40 is the call instruction.
[]Instruction 6 is an unconditional jump, i.e., a goto instruction.
[]Instructions 7-10 and 31-32 are conditional jump instructions.
[]Instruction 37 concatenates strings.[/ul]

Read full topic
